intro: Draba solitaria, commonly known as the solitary whitlow grass, is a small flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is native to arctic and alpine regions of the Northern Hemisphere, including North America, Europe, and Asia. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to cold, harsh environments. It produces small, white or yellowish flowers in early spring, and its leaves are basal, linear, and often covered in fine hairs. Draba solitaria is an important component of alpine ecosystems and is often used in horticulture for its hardy nature and ornamental value.
